title: 103_s1493
content: The Act is titled the "South African Democratic Transition Support Act of 1993". The Congress finds that South Africa's transition from apartheid to democracy is a historic opportunity supported by the international community for stability and economic development in the region. Representative leaders in South Africa, including Nelson Mandela, have called for an end to economic restrictions in the region, citing the detrimental impact on those affected by apartheid. The United States policy is outlined in Section 3. The Congress supports the Transitional Executive Council in South Africa and urges progress towards a nonracial democratic government. The United States should provide assistance for the transition to democracy and consult with international financial institutions. The United States should work closely with international financial institutions, donors, and South African entities to support the transition to a nonracial democracy. To address historical inequities from apartheid, the US should promote private enterprise, free markets, and encourage the South African private sector to provide ownership, advancement, training, and employment opportunities for disadvantaged South Africans. The United States should encourage private sector investment and trade with South Africa, urge South Africa to liberalize trade policies, promote regional cooperation for stability and growth, and support the transition to a nonracial democracy in South Africa. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF APARTHEID SANCTIONS LAWS AND OTHER PROVISIONS DIRECTED AT SOUTH AFRICA. Repeal of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986, except for specified sections, upon certification of an interim government in South Africa elected through free and fair elections. Amendments made to certain sections of the Act. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 provisions repealed by the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986 are specified. Amendments are made to section 116(e)(1) of the Act. Additionally, subsections (c) and (d) of the International Security and Development Cooperation Act of 1985 are repealed. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 provisions repealed by various Acts, including the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986, are specified. Sections from different Foreign Relations Authorization Acts and the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 are repealed. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 provisions repealed by various Acts, including the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986, are specified. Sections from different Acts are amended or repealed, including sanctions measures adopted by State or local governments or private entities regarding economic interactions with South Africa. SEC. 5. United States assistance for the transition to a nonracial democracy. The President is authorized to provide assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act to support the transition to nonracial democracy in South Africa, focusing on building the capacity of disadvantaged South Africans and working with local organizations. The assistance provided under the Foreign Assistance Act aims to increase the capacity of South African institutions to serve individuals disadvantaged by apartheid, support education through scholarships for disadvantaged students, fund nontraditional training activities, prepare for elections, end violence, and promote human rights and democratization. Assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act is limited for the Government of South Africa unless an interim government elected through free and fair elections is in place. Exceptions include support for the Transitional Executive Council and disadvantaged higher education institutions. The Foreign Assistance Act limits assistance to the Government of South Africa unless there is an interim government elected through free and fair elections. Exceptions include support for the Transitional Executive Council and disadvantaged higher education institutions. Assistance may also be provided to organizations promoting the transition to nonracial democracy in South Africa, based on consultations with South African individuals and organizations representative of the majority population. SEC. 6. UNITED STATES INVESTMENT AND TRADE. The President should negotiate a tax treaty with South Africa to facilitate US investment. Initiatives with OPIC and the Trade and Development Agency should be expanded to promote investment in South Africa. The Export-Import Bank should increase activities related to exports to South Africa. Promoting disadvantaged enterprises through investment and trade programs is also recommended. The agencies should promote business enterprises in South Africa majority-owned by disadvantaged South Africans. The US government should make efforts to assist business enterprises with over 50% ownership by nonwhite South Africans in procurement activities. The Director of the United States Information Agency should utilize the authorities of the United States Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948 to support the establishment of a nonracial democracy in South Africa. Additionally, the President should aim to establish cooperative agreements with South Africa on various issues, including cultural and scientific matters. The President should encourage other donors, like Japan and the European Community countries, to support South Africa's transition to nonracial democracy. The Secretary of the Treasury should instruct relevant international financial institutions to increase lending and financial assistance to South Africa for the same purpose. SEC. 10. CONSULTATION WITH SOUTH AFRICANS. The President shall consult closely with South African individuals and organizations representative of the majority population in South Africa and others committed to abolishing apartheid.
